scene.name: intro
scene.line: `(DONALD puffs on a smoldering pipe while half-mumbling, half-singing an old country tune.)`
`(Softly.)` ... where the old green river runs, through hills and caves not known to us, down to that sunless sea ...
Oh! Who are you?

scene.name: startle
scene.line: I might say you did! I thought you might be one of them ...
Oh, no. You can't be. We've been patching all their spy-holes. We keep the lights dim and the motors running softly, and we route the smoke out through ... out through ...

scene.name: whats-that-song
scene.line: Oh, you've caught a verse of my absent-minded warbling. It's just a song from my ... youth. Something a dear friend used to sing to herself as we hacked on crystal radios in the boiler room.
`(Singing.)` "In old Kentucky, where my love / a lovely home did build for me / and where the old green river runs / through hills and caves not known to us / down to that sunless sea ... "
From there on, it's all meandering rivers and romantic greenery, and ...

scene.name: donald-lost-one
scene.line: ... that is ... what were we talking about?
scene.option: What's that computer over there? Looks pretty vintage.

scene.name: the-road
scene.line: Ah, you came from the road. The |Zero|. No, you should stay off that road. Not safe. Bizarre topology. You'll never get anywhere. It just brings you right back here.
scene.option: The bridge is out down there.
What's that you're working on? Looks pretty vintage.

scene.name: zero-back-to-cave
scene.line: Always back to this spot. It's a prison. An irrational prison ...

scene.name: bridge-out
scene.line: Hm. Yes. We're quite `marooned` in this moment ...

scene.name: donald-trapped
scene.line: But I don't mind. Not anymore. This is where my life's work is. The computer. Right on the other side of the spire.

scene.name: computer
scene.line: It looks like a harmless old computer, doesn't it? Like some beat-up mainframe exhumed from a university basement and left in this cave to rot ... or to flower!
No, it's no ordinary computer. I've modified it extensively, and in some pretty `experimental` ways, believe you me! And that's to say nothing of the software, but ...
`(To SHANNON.)` You look like a technically-minded sort of person. Tell me: do you know the effects of mold growth on diffused-base transistor circuitry?
scene.option: Sounds like it would short circuit.

scene.name: computer-mold-short-circuit
scene.line: Certainly, certainly ... but not all of it. Some moldy filaments are more or less conductive than others, and it grows in non-linear, chaotic patterns. We can guide it a bit, through a simple application of classical horticulture, but we can't produce specific results, only `tendencies`.

scene.name: computer-mold-burn
scene.line: Exactly. It burns, and oh the sweet smoke that issues from it! But it also leaves a sticky residue to seep through the machine, forming new connections and creating new circuits. The computer is no longer the pure domain of language or mathematics, but entropy.

scene.name: computer-entropy
scene.line: Thwarted and feeble, we hammer on this derelict keyboard: `"MY NAME IS REASON, KING OF KINGS!"`
But we are mere touristsgardeners in the ruins. Our keystrokes echo off into the tunnels ... boundless and bare, the caves stretch far away. We are too late. Always too late ...

scene.name: xanadu-start
scene.line: ... what? Did you say something?
scene.option: You were about to tell us about the software.
I'm just interested in the mold computer.

scene.name: xanadu-software
scene.line: Oh, the software! My life's work ... `XANADU`. You've heard of it?

scene.name: xanadu-mold
scene.line: The "mold computer" ... the ... ? Oh, `XANADU`! You've heard about it!

scene.name: heard-about-xanadu
scene.line: Perhaps you've read about it in a journal? It's been years since I published anything. `XANADU` has evolved significantly since I explained its data structures in my article `Literary Multitudes: Hypertextual Narrative as Poststructural Witness`.

Evolved ... and then deteriorated. `(DONALD sighs dramatically, and takes a puff from his pipe.)` I'm afraid you are too late, fellow hypertext enthusiast. As the mold accumulated on the circuitry, `XANADU` blossomed for a moment into something holy and enchanted ... then all the charm was broken.
Do you have any idea what it's like to spend your life building something, and then sit powerlessly as your work declines into ruin?
scene.option: I drive deliveries for a small antique shop, and we're closing down.
I fix TVs and I'm about to lose the lease on my workshop.
My family disappeared; Julian and me don't know what to do.

scene.name: antique-shop
scene.line: Ah, shuffling around the dusty ghosts of antiquity ...

scene.name: tv-shop
scene.line: Oh! They are not long, the days of electron guns and cathode rays. Out of a glowing dream, a ghostly light emerges for a while, then fades ...

scene.name: family
scene.line: So! Wandering without the ones who give us purpose ... like a ghost ...

scene.name: not-really
scene.line: Ah! Then I hope you never have occasion to be haunted by the ghosts of missed opportunities ...

scene.name: xanadu-description
scene.line: Well. I have my own ghosts. And I keep them in `there`. In `XANADU`. It's running on that glorious, dusty machine. Take a look if you'd like. Too late to do anything but smoke and reminisce, anyway ... far too late to do anything ...
